Article.ArticleTitle: Sustained Area-Selectivity in Atomic Layer Deposition of Ir Films: Utilization of Dual Effects of O<sub>3</sub> in Deposition and Etching.

AbstractText: Area-selective deposition (ASD) based on self-aligned technology has emerged as a promising solution for resolving misalignment issues during ultrafine patterning processes. Despite its potential, the problems of area-selectivity losing beyond a certain thickness remain critical in ASD applications. This study reports a novel approach to sustain the area-selectivity of Ir films as the thickness increases. Ir films are deposited on Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> as the growth area and SiO<sub>2</sub> as the non-growth area using atomic-layer-deposition with tricarbonyl-(1,2,3-η)-1,2,3-tri(tert-butyl)-cyclopropenyl-iridium and O<sub>3</sub>. O<sub>3</sub> exhibits a dual effect, facilitating both deposition and etching. In the steady-state growth regime, O<sub>3</sub> solely contributes to deposition, whereas in the initial growth stages, longer exposure to O<sub>3</sub> etches the initially formed isolated Ir nuclei through the formation of volatile IrO<sub>3</sub>. Importantly, longer O<sub>3</sub> exposure is required for the initial etching on the growth area(Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) compared to the non-growth area(SiO<sub>2</sub>). By controlling the O<sub>3</sub> injection time, the area selectivity is sustained even above a thickness of 25 nm by suppressing nucleation on the non-growth area. These findings shed light on the fundamental mechanisms of ASD using O<sub>3</sub> and offer a promising avenue for advancing thin-film technologies. Furthermore, this approach holds promise for extending ASD to other metals susceptible to forming volatile species.
